technology costs is often constrained by the
lack of information on public and/
or private energy R&D investments in many fast
reductions varies across technologies, even within the same model, depending on
maturity. Less mature technologies generally depend highly on learning
doing dominates in more mature technologies
nowledge spillover effects are also integrated in climate
models to reflect the fact that innovation in a given country depends also on knowledge generated
can use spillover matrices to include bilateral spillo
learning rates that depend on the human capital stock and the regional and/or sectoral absorption rates
Accounting for knowledge spillovers in the EU
biofuels, industry materials, batteries and advanced heating and cooking appliances
postponing action for the period after 2030
ndogenous technical progress in the green technologies
alleviates most of the negative effects of pioneering low
rely on assumptions about the cost of a given technology cost relative to the costs of other technologies
and its ability to supply the energy demand under the relevant energy system and physi
These assumptions include, for example, considerations regarding renewable intermittency, inertia on
technology lifetime (for instance, under less stringent temperature scenarios early retirement of fossil
plants does not take place), dist
ribution, capacity and market growth constraints, as well as the presence
of policies. These factors change the relative price of technologies. Furthermore, technological diffusion
in one country is also influenced by technology advancements in other regio
Technology diffusion may also be strongly influenced, either positi
vely or negatively, by a number of
technological barriers or enablers regarding behaviours, society and institutions
These include network or infrastructure externalities, the co
technology clusters over time (“path dependence”), the risk
aversion of users, personal preferences and
lack of adequate institutional framework which may negatively influence the speed of
carbon) technological innovation and diffusion, heterogeneous agents with different preferences
presence and the level of environmental policies and institutional and administrative barriers
2015; Baker et al. 2015; Marangoni and Tavoni 2014; van Sluisveld et al. 202
These types of barriers to technology diffusion are currently not explicitly
detailed in most of the climate
economy models. Rather, they are accounted for in models
through scenario narratives, such as the ones in the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways
in which assumptions about technology adoption are s
panned over a plausible range of values.
Complementary methods are increasingly used to explore their importance in future scenarios
(Turnheim et al. 2015; Gambhir et al. 2019; Trutnevyte et al. 2019; Doukas et al. 2018; Geels et al.
It takes a very complex modelling framework to include all aspects affecting technology cost
s and technology diffusion, such as heterogeneous agents
